body:
at first glance it seems a very outdated library that no longer works (and messes with readline) is installed

https://pypi.org/project/pyreadline/2.1/ was last released in 2015 and doesn't correctly work on modern python3

@nicoddemus the pytest readline workaround for windows mentions this library specifically, it seems like we need to blacklist it on modern python+pytest

its really unfortunate if support libs go unmaintained that way

@domdfcoding As a far I can see there is neither humanfriendly nor pyreadline in the dependency tree:

```shell
$ pipdeptree --python .tox/py310/bin/python 
coverage==5.5
gstore==0.5.0
  - gitpython [required: >=3.0.6, installed: 3.1.17]
    - gitdb [required: >=4.0.1,<5, installed: 4.0.7]
      - smmap [required: >=3.0.1,<5, installed: 4.0.0]
  - pygithub [required: >=1.55, installed: 1.55]
    - deprecated [required: Any, installed: 1.2.12]
      - wrapt [required: >=1.10,<2, installed: 1.12.1]
    - pyjwt [required: >=2.0, installed: 2.1.0]
    - pynacl [required: >=1.4.0, installed: 1.4.0]
      - cffi [required: >=1.4.1, installed: 1.14.5]
        - pycparser [required: Any, installed: 2.20]
      - six [required: Any, installed: 1.16.0]
    - requests [required: >=2.14.0, installed: 2.25.1]
      - certifi [required: >=2017.4.17, installed: 2021.5.30]
      - chardet [required: >=3.0.2,<5, installed: 4.0.0]
      - idna [required: >=2.5,<3, installed: 2.10]
      - urllib3 [required: >=1.21.1,<1.27, installed: 1.26.5]
pip==21.1.2
pytest==6.2.4
  - attrs [required: >=19.2.0, installed: 21.2.0]
  - iniconfig [required: Any, installed: 1.1.1]
  - packaging [required: Any, installed: 20.9]
    - pyparsing [required: >=2.0.2, installed: 2.4.7]
  - pluggy [required: >=0.12,<1.0.0a1, installed: 0.13.1]
  - py [required: >=1.8.2, installed: 1.10.0]
  - toml [required: Any, installed: 0.10.2]
setuptools==57.0.0
wheel==0.36.2
```

However, I'm not a Windows user, and this output was received in macOs.  Probably something is hidden here:
https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/8300b266a8e48b7db2240ae5b52632f018d2c0bd/src/_pytest/capture.py#L88-L92

As you could see above, in the stacktrace I provided pytest calls readline and readline calls pyreadline:
pytest -> readline -> [pyreadline](https://github.com/pyreadline/pyreadline)

The last commit to pyreadline was on 14 Jul 2015 and it looks like it does not support Python 3.10.
@sergeyklay dependencies are platform-dependent, doing a deptree on macos does not tell you what will be installed on windows

I have no idea what has changed, but now the build and test are passing! I just waited a few days and tried again. I suspect that due to the fact that I rewrote some [conf]tests, some functionality that requires pyreadline is no longer called. However, unfortunately I cannot determine what exactly

Btw, I managed to get the full dependency tree in GitHub Actions using Python 3.10 on Windows, and agin, there is neither humanfriendly nor pyreadline ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ :

```coverage==5.5
furo==2020.12.30b24
  - beautifulsoup4 [required: Any, installed: 4.9.3]
    - soupsieve [required: >1.2, installed: 2.2.1]
  - sphinx [required: ~=3.0, installed: 3.5.4]
    - alabaster [required: >=0.7,<0.8, installed: 0.7.12]
    - babel [required: >=1.3, installed: 2.9.1]
      - pytz [required: >=2015.7, installed: 2021.1]
    - colorama [required: >=0.3.5, installed: 0.4.4]
    - docutils [required: >=0.12,<0.17, installed: 0.16]
    - imagesize [required: Any, installed: 1.2.0]
    - Jinja2 [required: >=2.3, installed: 3.0.1]
      - MarkupSafe [required: >=2.0, installed: 2.0.1]
    - packaging [required: Any, installed: 20.9]
      - pyparsing [required: >=2.0.2, installed: 2.4.7]
    - Pygments [required: >=2.0, installed: 2.9.0]
    - requests [required: >=2.5.0, installed: 2.25.1]
      - certifi [required: >=2017.4.17, installed: 2021.5.30]
      - chardet [required: >=3.0.2,<5, installed: 4.0.0]
      - idna [required: >=2.5,<3, installed: 2.10]
      - urllib3 [required: >=1.21.1,<1.27, installed: 1.26.5]
    - setuptools [required: Any, installed: 56.0.0]
    - snowballstemmer [required: >=1.1, installed: 2.1.0]
    - sphinxcontrib-applehelp [required: Any, installed: 1.0.2]
    - sphinxcontrib-devhelp [required: Any, installed: 1.0.2]
    - sphinxcontrib-htmlhelp [required: Any, installed: 2.0.0]
    - sphinxcontrib-jsmath [required: Any, installed: 1.0.1]
    - sphinxcontrib-qthelp [required: Any, installed: 1.0.3]
    - sphinxcontrib-serializinghtml [required: Any, installed: 1.1.5]
gstore==0.5.0
  - gitpython [required: >=3.0.6, installed: 3.1.17]
    - gitdb [required: >=4.0.1,<5, installed: 4.0.7]
      - smmap [required: >=3.0.1,<5, installed: 4.0.0]
  - pygithub [required: >=1.55, installed: 1.55]
    - deprecated [required: Any, installed: 1.2.12]
      - wrapt [required: >=1.10,<2, installed: 1.12.1]
    - pyjwt [required: >=2.0, installed: 2.1.0]
    - pynacl [required: >=1.4.0, installed: 1.4.0]
      - cffi [required: >=1.4.1, installed: 1.14.5]
        - pycparser [required: Any, installed: 2.20]
      - six [required: Any, installed: 1.16.0]
    - requests [required: >=2.14.0, installed: 2.25.1]
      - certifi [required: >=2017.4.17, installed: 2021.5.30]
      - chardet [required: >=3.0.2,<5, installed: 4.0.0]
      - idna [required: >=2.5,<3, installed: 2.10]
      - urllib3 [required: >=1.21.1,<1.27, installed: 1.26.5]
pipdeptree==2.0.0
  - pip [required: >=6.0.0, installed: 21.1.2]
pytest==6.2.4
  - atomicwrites [required: >=1.0, installed: 1.4.0]
  - attrs [required: >=19.2.0, installed: 21.2.0]
  - colorama [required: Any, installed: 0.4.4]
  - iniconfig [required: Any, installed: 1.1.1]
  - packaging [required: Any, installed: 20.9]
    - pyparsing [required: >=2.0.2, installed: 2.4.7]
  - pluggy [required: >=0.12,<1.0.0a1, installed: 0.13.1]
  - py [required: >=1.8.2, installed: 1.10.0]
  - toml [required: Any, installed: 0.10.2]
tox-gh-actions==2.5.0
  - tox [required: >=3.12, installed: 3.23.1]
    - colorama [required: >=0.4.1, installed: 0.4.4]
    - filelock [required: >=3.0.0, installed: 3.0.12]
    - packaging [required: >=14, installed: 20.9]
      - pyparsing [required: >=2.0.2, installed: 2.4.7]
    - pluggy [required: >=0.12.0, installed: 0.13.1]
    - py [required: >=1.4.17, installed: 1.10.0]
    - six [required: >=1.14.0, installed: 1.16.0]
    - toml [required: >=0.9.4, installed: 0.10.2]
    - virtualenv [required: >=16.0.0,!=20.0.7,!=20.0.6,!=20.0.5,!=20.0.4,!=20.0.3,!=20.0.2,!=20.0.1,!=20.0.0, installed: 20.4.7]
      - appdirs [required: >=1.4.3,<2, installed: 1.4.4]
      - distlib [required: >=0.3.1,<1, installed: 0.3.2]
      - filelock [required: >=3.0.0,<4, installed: 3.0.12]
      - six [required: >=1.9.0,<2, installed: 1.16.0]
```

I'm going to close this issue and reopen it again if issue will arise in the future. But at the moment it seems automagically resolved to me.

i'd like to leave this open until @nicoddemus leans in with a opinion on the library detail/workaround

im glad it resolved, it may be a dependency just dropping the broken pyreadline due to the windows3.10 issues
Thanks for the clarification. Let's wait and see

issue.title: Pytest warning on readline

labels.name: type: deprecation
labels.description: feature that will be removed in the future

repository.name: pytest
repository.description: The pytest framework makes it easy to write small tests, yet scales to support complex functional testing

issue.body:
If I use pytest-6.2.4, pytest-cov 2.12.1 and python 3.9.4 on Windows 10

with following commands:

`pytest --cov src --cov-fail-under=98 --cov-report=term-missing`

or simply

`pytest`

I get a warning: 

..\..\app\winpython\python-3.9.4.amd64\lib\site-packages\pyreadline\py3k_compat.py:8
  c:\python_env\app\winpython\python-3.9.4.amd64\lib\site-packages\pyreadline\py3k_compat.py:8: DeprecationWarning: Using or importing the ABCs from 'collections' instead of from 'collections.abc' is deprecated since Python 3.3
, and in 3.10 it will stop working
    return isinstance(x, collections.Callable)

-- Docs: https://docs.pytest.org/en/stable/warnings.html

=> Could please replace pyreadline or somehow hide the warning?

Related: 
https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/8733
https://github.com/pyreadline/pyreadline/pull/68

issue.title: Drop readline workaround introduced in #1281

repository.name: pytest
repository.description: The pytest framework makes it easy to write small tests, yet scales to support complex functional testing

issue.body:
Fix #8733
Closes #8847

* Also add types-atomicwrites as extras to mypy pre-commit hook (Windows)

body:
Pretty sure I'm still seeing this same issue in the official minor release of 3.10 in GH actions:
https://github.com/goodboy/tractor/runs/4080120591?check_suite_focus=true#step:5:48

Not entirely sure how to fix it either after reading through #8848.

issue.title: Window: get python 3.10 tests running in CI

license.name: GNU Affero General Public License v3.0

issue.body:
There's some weird ass bug with `pyreadline` as per #259 which tracks down to something inside `pytest` (https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/8733, which led to https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/8847).

We likely need to re-factor the whole actions matrix anyway to simplify some things:
- don't duplicate job defs for `msgspec` and instead use a parameter
- make it easier to control filtering for diff OSs whether that's through `if` controls or wtv..

Relevant GH actions resources,
- https://stackoverflow.com/questions/65384420/how-to-make-a-github-action-matrix-element-conditional
- https://docs.github.com/en/actions/learn-github-actions/managing-complex-workflows#using-a-build-matrix
-  https://docs.github.com/en/actions/learn-github-actions/workflow-syntax-for-github-actions#jobsjob_idstrategymatrix
-  https://docs.github.com/en/actions/learn-github-actions/workflow-syntax-for-github-actions#jobsjob_idif
-  https://docs.github.com/en/actions/learn-github-actions/expressions
